Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Program in Nanotechnology for Biology and Bioengineering
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Johns Hopkins University, located in Baltimore, MD, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2015- 2017. This award is supported by the Division of Biological Infrastructure in the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO/DBI) and the Division of Engineering Education and Centers in the Directorate for Engineering (ENG/EEC). The proposed REU will provide undergraduate students with challenging research experience in the rapidly growing area of nanobiotechnology, a discipline at the interface of biology, chemistry, physics, materials science, and engineering. Students work on interdisciplinary projects and interact with researchers from several academic departments ? Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Materials Science and Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Physics, and Chemistry. Example projects include the development of safe carriers for in vivo gene transfer, engineering skeletal muscles, molecular mechanics of cell shape change, 3D printing of microvessels, and others. In addition to research, students participate in orientation, ethics and safety training, graduate school preparation, resume building, and a poster presentation at the end of the program. Students with limited opportunities for research at their home institution and those from underrepresented groups will be recruited to the program. Students will be selected based on academic record, letters of recommendation, and their statement of purpose.

It is anticipated that over 3 summers, a total of 30 students will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at regional and national conferences. Upon completing the program, REU students will have a greater understanding of the development and applications of nanotechnology in biology, a solid grounding in research methodologies in these areas, and a deeper appreciation for the contributions that improved technology in these areas can make to people's lives.

Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://inbt.jhu.edu/education/undergraduate/reu/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Wirtz at wirtz@jhu.edu), the co-PI (Dr. Herrera-Alonso at herrera@jhu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Johns Hopkins University REU program in Nanotechnology for Biology and Bioengineering, housed within the Institute for NanoBioTechnology, provided summer research training for 12 students in summer of 2018. The cohort included seven women and six minorities. The program attracted an application pool of 611 highly diverse undergraduate students. 

This REU has met its overall goal of having its interns participate in a unique research, educational, and professional experience with research being the focus. This REU program laid the foundation for interest in graduate research, future student presentations, and published papers. After the REU experience, the eleven interns surveyed reported that they are likely or very likely to pursue a PhD program in STEM in the future. Additionally, all of them reported that they are likely or very likely to pursue a career that includes research.

The REU interns performed research in labs across different divisions of Johns Hopkins University within participating departments: biomedical engineering, radiology, mechanical engineering, chemical and biomolecular engineering, and materials science and engineering.  The program has worked with 12 faculty mentors and labs to ensure a diverse range of opportunity for research interest in biomaterials, bioengineering, biophysics, nanofabrication, cell engineering, and tissue engineering

REU interns participated in seminars and various workshops focusing on topics such as responsible conduct of research, oral presentations, publishing, graduate school admissions, creating a scientific poster, and a journal club. The development workshops are in addition to a scientific seminar series, where the interns learned about career paths and cutting-edge research from distinguished faculty. The interns gave oral and poster presentations of their research. Students fully participated in lab research and projects that have an intellectual merit.  Examples of projects during the summer of 2018 include:

  • Using a kidney-on –a-chip model for kidney disease
  • Purifying antibodies to find new methods in strengthening the immune system
  • Fabrication of monolayers in an in vitro 3D engineered microvessel model.
  • Liposome−microbead conjugation formation and analysis
  • Effects of hypoxia on pluripotent stem cells

This program was able to introduce undergraduates to exciting developments with emphasis on engineering for cancer therapies, diagnostic tools engineered for early detection, and stem cell and regenerative engineering. REU students were vital in the planning and progress in all projects they were assigned.  These projects promoted learning, skill development, career exploration, and teaching.  At the end of the summer, the students presented posters on their work at the School of Medicine’s CARES Symposium.

Alumni from the 2018 cohort have gone on to pursue PhD programs at Cornell University, University of Pennsylvania, and our own Johns Hopkins University. Another graduate is interning at Merck.  Those who have not yet graduated are interning at Fraunhofer Institute for Interfacial Engineering and Biotechnology and Dow Chemical. One alumni has been endowed with the MARC award.

Overall, the program in Nanotechnology for Biology and Bioengineering, has attracted, trained, and mentored a diverse group of students.
